<h1 style="color: cyan; text-align: center">100 Day's Of Cybersecurity - Day 1</h1>

![](https://github.com/thelocalh0st/thelocalh0st.github.io/assets/95465072/8773b3bb-4ed9-4203-9d13-6f7ad19da2d9)

## Challenge Description 

WearRansom ransomware just got loose in our company. The SOC has traced the initial access to a phishing attack, a Word document with macros. Take a look at the document and see if you can find anything else about the malware and perhaps a flag.

## Initial Forensics Analysis

CISA has an  [Page called -Emottet Malware](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/alerts/aa20-280a)  that goes into detail about this malware, how it propogates, and how it functions. If we go to the bottom of that page it lists some attack techniques documented by  [MITRE](https://attack.mitre.org/versions/v7/software/S0367/). There are several techniques that are relevant to how I’ll approach this challenge:

-   Emotet has sent Microsoft Word documents with embedded macros that will invoke scripts to download additional payloads.
-   Emotet has obfuscated macros within malicious documents to hide the URLs hosting the malware, CMD.exe arguments, and PowerShell scripts.
-   Emotet has used cmd.exe to run a PowerShell script.
-   Emotet has used Powershell to retrieve the malicious payload and download additional resources like Mimikatz.


## Investigating Malicious Documents

```bash
root@kali $ md5sum emo.doc
c578a9fc241658517a7346a2a60236c84f0bb4919b857db226150aab4093451e
```

<img width="960" alt="Screenshot 2023-12-10 212832" src="https://github.com/thelocalh0st/thelocalh0st.github.io/assets/95465072/641cf543-43b2-4a16-b1fa-96fcd1633f68">

**You can also read the virus total comments / Community section to see the detaild analysis report by the community**

> Office documents can be Unzipped and have a ton of XML and metadata included.
{: .prompt-warning }

<br>

>There are tools that will analyze an Office doc to see if there are any macros, that SANS document lists a python script called  `Oledump`  that can extract macro data.
{: .prompt-tip }



## File Metadata

```sh
┌──(root㉿kali)-[/home/kali/Desktop/challenge-files]
└─# file emo.doc                           
emo.doc: Composite Document File V2 Document, Little Endian, Os: Windows, Version 10.0, Code page: 1252, Subject: Handmade Argentina Handcrafted Frozen Towels yellow Frozen virtual Guatemala array Lesotho JBOD, Template: Normal.dotm, Revision Number: 1, Name of Creating Application: Microsoft Office Word, Create Time/Date: Sat Oct 31 00:48:00 2020, Last Saved Time/Date: Tue Nov  3 02:14:00 2020, Number of Pages: 1, Number of Words: 9339, Number of Characters: 53237, Security: 8
        
```



## Dumping Office Macros 

```bash
┌──(root㉿kali)-[/home/kali/Desktop/challenge-files]
└─# olevba emo.doc
olevba 0.60.1 on Python 3.11.6 - http://decalage.info/python/oletools
===============================================================================
FILE: emo.doc
Type: OLE
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
VBA MACRO Dw75ayd2hpcab6.cls 
in file: emo.doc - OLE stream: 'Macros/VBA/Dw75ayd2hpcab6'
- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - 
Private Sub Document_open()
Get4ipjzmjfvp.X8twf_cydt6
End Sub
Function X4al3i4glox(Gav481k8nh28)
X4al3i4glox = Replace(Gav481k8nh28, "][(s)]w", Sxybmdt069cn)
End Function
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

+----------+--------------------+---------------------------------------------+
|Type      |Keyword             |Description                                  |
+----------+--------------------+---------------------------------------------+
|AutoExec  |Document_open       |Runs when the Word or Publisher document is  |
|          |                    |opened                                       |
|Suspicious|Create              |May execute file or a system command through |
|          |                    |WMI                                          |
|Suspicious|CreateObject        |May create an OLE object                     |
|Suspicious|ChrW                |May attempt to obfuscate specific strings    |
|          |                    |(use option --deobf to deobfuscate)          |
|Suspicious|Hex Strings         |Hex-encoded strings were detected, may be    |
|          |                    |used to obfuscate strings (option --decode to|
|          |                    |see all)                                     |

```



## Deobfuscation

we need to deobfuscate this mess, and we know that the malware executes some code as soon as the user opens the file. Leaning on my background in programming, that means at some point in this mess of text there is going to be an entry point of which our payload is being called from. So we need to find hints of functions being called.

If we go back to those txt files we made from  `oledump`  outputs, we can examine the files

```
Private Sub Document_open()
Get4ipjzmjfvp.X8twf_cydt6
End Sub
Function X4al3i4glox(Gav481k8nh28)
X4al3i4glox = Replace(Gav481k8nh28, "][(s)]w", Sxybmdt069cn)
End Function
```

I assumed that  `Document_open()`  was a function that is called when the document is opened… 

 So this  `Get4ipjzmjfvp.X8twf_cydt6`  is potentially our entry point to the payload.

## The Trojan  

![/images/htb/challenges/forensics/emo/enable1.png](https://0xv1n.github.io/images/htb/challenges/forensics/emo/enable1.png)


## Dynamic Analysis -- [app.any.run](https://app.any.run/tasks/b35e3e6a-257d-489a-8b3b-81f9d4b05c3d/)

<img width="960" alt="Screenshot 2023-12-10 212517" src="https://github.com/thelocalh0st/thelocalh0st.github.io/assets/95465072/ebab4bb9-2c57-4463-9e1d-39400cb9a357">

Through Dynamic analysis we can see the **DNS Connections** with this we can say that this might be the command and control connections

```
da-industrial.htb
daprofesional.htb
www.outspokenvisions.htb
dagranitegiare.htb
mobsouk.htb
biglaughs.htb
ngllogistics.htb
```

## The Payload

```powershell
POwersheLL -windowstyle hidden -ENCOD               

```

**After formatting this messy payload**

![a3761e2d95392443ff3ec40d77ce34cd-3495940740](https://github.com/thelocalh0st/thelocalh0st.github.io/assets/95465072/557f8bda-ea6c-4eee-884c-3ab1ee45d32d)

```powershell
                ${FN5`GGm`Sh} += ([byte][char]${_} -bxor 0xdf )

            ([wmiclass](('wi'+'n')+('32_'+'Proc'+'e')+'s'+'s'))."cR`eaTE"($Scusbkj);
            $Glwki6a = ('I'+'m'+('td'+'xv6'));
            break;
            $Pfpblh1 = ('Vs'+('lal'+'c')+'u')

$F47ief2 = (('Bn'+'zid')+'rt')
```
There’s something that immediately sticks out to me, and that’s all the numbers in this format:

`$FN5ggmsH += (186,141,228,182,177,171,229,236,239,239,239,228,181,182,171,229,234,239,239,228)`

`$FN5ggmsH += (185,179,190,184,229,151,139,157,164,235,177,239,171,183,236,141,128,187,235,134,128,158,177,176,139)`

`$FN5ggmsH += (183,154,173,128,175,151,238,140,183,162,228,170,173,179,229)`


## Lets Decode

CyberChef

I wanted to revert these potential Unicode encoded characters back to their original text state. This can be accomplished by using the `From Charcode` recipe - of which we’ll set the Base to 10 and the delimiter to a comma.

We can see in the payload that it's been `xor` with the key `0xdf` so lets put this receipe in cybechef
